div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,598] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.

div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905
"A good article recommends itself."
HOWIES Butter is no exception
Awarded Twelve 1st Prize Medals at the Khedivial Agricultural Show 1902, 1903 and 1905.
GIVE IT A TRIAL.
Address: Shubra Road, Cairo. 24-5-907

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.p: A perfect food is Bovril—it nourishes, stimulates and reinvigorates. Bovril is of great value for all to whom strength and endurance are a vital necessity. Its regular use is a permanent protection against the dangers of fcolds, chills and diseases.

div.head: Sudan Government.
NOTICE.
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to entre into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in presence of an official or other reliable witness. 28283A-30-10-906

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.

The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1906.

div.head: THE LATEST POLITICAL DISEASE.
div.p: ''The Morning Post" says : "The latest political disease is 'Pan-Mania' .... Fundamen- tally, of course, the prefix 'Pan' indicates that all the scattered parts of the race, nation, country, or religion are to be united, but very considerable variations from this 'motif' are permitted. . . . Two of the greatest of the 'Pans' overlap very seriously—Pan-Germans in Brazil and the Argentine mast be difficult to place in a Pan-American system. When we come to the second great 'Pan' we are on firmer ground. Pan-Germanism is not all coherent, but it has a solid foundation. The Pan-German cult expands itself in one direction to recover for Germany (not intellectually only but politically) the peoples of Teutonio stock who are not Germane (though they speak the German tongue the Swiss and Austrians, and the Low German peoples, the Dutch, Belgians (and even the Boers) while in another direction it spreads to the Colonies of Germans on German soil, and even to the small German settlements in towns and countries which are not German. Pan-Germanism has an organisation not confined to one body bot ramifying through hundreds of associations, political, economic, and even religions. They are not called Pan-Germanic societies, nor are they openly affiliated to the League which bears that name, bat-they are informed with the Pan-German spirit, helped with Pan- German foods, and (with different degrees of zeal) press for the seemed. Pan Germanism is not a political party in Germany, but a cult or ideal which can be adopted by any party. In Austria, however, the Pan-Germans actually go to the polls and sit in Parliament as such. They are at present the only 'Pans' of any kind to do so. Pan-Slavism, in its broadest sense, as implying a league or union of the Slav peoples, is little more than an impious aspiration. The Czechs, who are the most advanced of all the Slav races, would always want to lead, and this privilege would never be accorded by any of the others. The elimination of Russia (for the time being at all events) precludes the idea of a Pan Slav union in the Near East under her august patronage and protection. Such as it is, however, Pan Slavism altogether overshadows the little Pan-Hellenic propaganda which is Greece's latest contribution to the happiness of the world. Pan-Buddhism has a powerful propaganda to day in China, which aims at rousing the national and racial pride of the Orientals and inducing them to develop on their own lines and not on Western ones. The singular feature of Pan-Islam is that, as a name, an idea, a 'motif to be interpreted by each man after his kind, it is at present uniting a very considerable proportion of the world's population, and, unlikely other 'Pan,' it has no limitation, ethnographic, geographic, or national."

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The second performance of the ballet Les Poupées Animées, which was to have been given this afternoon at the San Stefano Theatre, has been cancelled owing to the indisposition of several of the children taking part. The usual children's al fresco ball will be held this afternoon, with the Bracale Orchestra. Chocolate will be given to the children of subscribers. The following is the menu of to-morrow's dinner : —
Consommé doubla glacé.
Dames da bar A la Kiborimne
Mignons de bœuf Nivernaiw
Pilaff A U Ktrasbourgvoiaa
Haricots varia A l'anglaise
Dindonneau réti Broche
Malade do Saison
Parfait au Moka
Patisserie assortie
Grand Dessert
H.H. the Khedive has left for Constantinople. (Havas)

M. Bourgeois has sent a diplomatist to Aix- les-Baine to announce to Prince George that the Consuls at Canea will communicate the Prince's Note of the 14th August, concerning the appointment of the High Commissioner, to the Cretan Assembly. (Havas)
M. Stolypin has refused the Constitutional Democrats permission to meet in congress here. The assembly will therefore be held in Finland or Sweden. ( Reuter)

div.head:
THE CHINESE CUSTOMS.
"TIMES" AND CHINESE ASSURANCES.

div.p: The "Times" strongly comments on the inadequacy of the Chinese assurances with regard to the position of Sir Robert Hart The paper adds : "If Great Britain accepts those assurances as the best solution discoverable we shall not have to wait long for equally flagrant breaches of treaty rights." (Reuter)

div.head:
GERMAN ARMY.
FOREIGN CRITICS ON MANCEUVRES.

div.p: Foreign critics at the German manœuvres were impressed by the endurance shown by the troops, hot were surprised et the close formation adopted "by the infantry for frontal attacks and the absence of head covering in trenches, in spits of the lessons of the Russo- Japanese war. ( Reuter )

div.head:
ALDERSHOT MANCEUVRES.
ENGLAND INVADED BY IRELAND.

div.p: The army manœnvres, conducted by General Sir John French, with naval officers cooperating, have begun at Aldershot. The idea of the manceuvres is the invasion of England by Ireland after having defeated the fleet. (R.)
An Army Order of the day constitutes General Staff consisting of 57 officers at head quarters and 114 in commands in districts. (Reuter)
Two more warships have been despatched to Cuba. (Reuter)
Prince Albrecht of Prussia, Regent of Brunswick, is dead. (Reuter)

The Regent of the Duchy of Brunswick, Prince Frederick William Nicholas Albert of Prussia, was the son of the Kaiser's great- uncle and was born in Berlin in 1987. He had been Regent of Brunswick since 1885. He married in 1854 the Princess of Sixe-Altenburg, by whom he had three sons.

div.head: British Soldier Injured.
div.p: A British private was knocked over and injored by a tram on Tuesday near the El Tewfikieh Pharmacy, Cairo.

div.head: British Man-of-War.
div.p: H.M.S Venus, coming from Port Said to Alexandria, was sighted by the Kom el-Dik signalling station as we went to press.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Today's bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria and another at Suez. The patient at Alexandria is a native living in the Customhouse quarter.

div.head: The Sudan.
div.p: A new work on the Sudan by Dr. B. A. Wallis Budge is to be published shortly, entitled "The Egyptian Sudan, its History and Monuments."

div.head: Gum Arabic,
div.p: At the London gum auctions on the 6th inst. the only gum arabic sold was 22 bags of Australians. Its quality was a fair glassy red, a little blocky, at 60s.

div.head: -Mex-les-Bains.
div.p: At 5.30 this afternoon, the Compagnia Volcanica dei Diavoli Rossi, vocalists and instramentalists, will make their debut at the Mex Casino, to which admission is free.

div.head: Esbekish Court Scandals.
div.p: The recent revelations as to embezzlements in the Esbekieh Summary Court have led the Cairo Parquet to arrest Ali Abdel-Raouf Eff., a clerk of the court, who is suspected of the defalcations.

div.head: Execution.
div.p: Hassan Ali El-Adli, of Rahmanieb, Behera Mondirish, who has been sentenced to death for the murder of his uncle, aunt, and their servant, as already related in our columns, will be executed in Hadra prison on Monday next at 7.30 a.m.

div.head: Egyptian Salt and Soda.
div.p: Application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to allow the following secarity to be quoted in the Official List: Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, Limited- Further issue of 150,000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each fully paid.

div.head: Alexandria Swimming Club.
div.p: The committee inform us that the club's new floating bath is ready for use, and that a steam launch will leave the Marina to-morrow at 3.15 p.m., for Ras el Tin. Members and friends are requested to meet in full force, especially those competing in the sports, for the purpose of having their times taken.

div.head: Sudden Death.
div.p: While Mr. Constantine Evangelidis was taking a cup of coffee this morning in the Café du Nil near the Alexandria Bourse, he felt a slight paia in his head, so he walked to Mr. Ruelberg's pharmacy to get some medicine. A doctor was called, but before the latter's arrival he had expired from heart disease.

div.head: Not Wanted.
div.p: The Cairo police found an infant of the female sex lying in Sharia El-Nabi, Mousky quarter, two days ago. Close beside it was a slip of paper with the following insoription in Greek: "This child is 20 days old and has not been baptised." The babe was taken to the Foundlings' Home, where she received the name of Anissch Abdalla.

div.head: Prince Line.
div.p: The gross profits for the year ended Jane 30 amounted to £109,684. After allowing for renewals and including £1,743 brought forward there is a disposable balance of £71,820. The directors devote £40,000 to depreciation, and propose a final dividend at the rate of 5 per cent., carrying forward £1,745. The distribution was the same a year ago.

div.head: The Shoubra Crime.
div.p: The communiqué of the French Consulate, exoqlpating M. Paillard, senior, of the Shoubra crime, by an alibi, came as a surprise to Cairo society, which would not now be taken aback were Paillard, janior, to bave the same favour bestowed on him. The dilatoriness in the enquiry is attributed by the French Consulate to the Native Court which has not yet officially communicated the results of its enquiry.

div.head: Ship Cut In Two.
div.p: While on the usual ran from Jaffa to Port Said, the Messageries steamer Sénégal, which reached Port Said on Wednesday, tan down a sailing craft, and cut her in two before she could stop. The crew of the vessel, seven in number, escaped in the dinghy, and were picked up. One of them was hart by the collision, but not seriously. The Sénégal was delayed four hours by the accident, which occurred sixty miles off Port Said and at two a.m. The sanken vessel carried no mast-
head lights.

div.head: Cairo Season.
div.p: Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt). Limited, bave issued a useful and artistic handbook giving the fallest details as to their arrangements for the coming tourist season in Egypt and on the Nile. To anyone contemplating a visit to Nile-land, this excellently got up little publication is a valuable vade mecum, giving as it does useful information regarding the many spots which may be visited and the various itineraries followed by the abiquitous Cook. The pamphlet contains a host of pretty illustrations. New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by membera requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head:
MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL
THE PROPOSED BANQUET.
div.p: The native press, having exhausted itself in discussing the many and various problems connected with the trestment of Helbawi Bey by Prince Mohamed Aly Pash, and the alleged secret interview of Abon Shadi Bey/ with Mr. Findlay, has now found a fresh source of inspiration in the approaching banquet, which is to be given in honour of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's return to his native land. We, however, deeply regret to notice that many of the leading journalistic laminaries of the nationalist newspaper world appear to be disposed to skalk in their tents in view of the splendid ovation that is to be given to the great protagonist of Egyptian nationalism. The lesser lights of the vernacular Anglophobe press naturally feel rather out of it, for "Al Minbar" and its brethren will suffer an eclipse when the editor of "Al Lewa" returns in all his glory.
"Mier" is of opinion that the banquet is premature. and that it should be postponed until the English have withdrawn from Egypt and the country has obtained complete independence!

A journalist writes to "Al Watan" to protest against the proposed banquet. He states that the Pasha does not deserve such an honour, as he has not rendered any services to the country, but is merely working for his own ends.The writer goes on to state that he has only distinguished himself by arousing bitterness between Moslem and Christian. and that it sach aban- quet be given, it will lead to a very bad impression in England.
The same paper publishes a telegram from Tantah to the effect that a large number of native notables there have decided to oppose the proposed scheme for honouring the Pasha.

An amusing example of nationalist fervour is seen in the proposal of one of the supporters of the Pasha that the "pièce de resistance" at the forthcoming banquet should be an Egyptian camel in honour of that serviceable creature's namesake. Whether one or more of these quadrupeds is to be cooked for the occasion we do not know, bat surely one would not be enough to go round among the many supporters of Kamel, who will flock to the banquet. The symbolic signification involved in such a dish will probably only be divulged to the initiates, bat, on the other hand, the idea may have been merely suggested by the simple coincidence of the names. No doubt this problem will be disoussed ad naustam in the columns of our con: temporaries, for the bill of fare is already leading to oriticism.

The idea of a "national" repast pure and simple has not met with universal approval, for it is recognised that if the banquet is solely confided to Egyptian dishes and drinks, the mena will hardly be to the taste of the hero of the evening, who has been accustomed in London to the gastronomic delicacies of the Carlton Hotel. The idea of an essentially "nationalistic" bill of fare is a good one, but it is somewhat difficult to realise. Possibly a compromise may be effected by varying the monotony with a few Tarkish dishes. We might venture to suggest a via media in the shape of a Pan-Islamic faast, which could thus embrace a variety of dishes, Moorish, Algerian, Tunisian, etc. Surely this would be the most. simple way out of the difficulty.

div.head: "AL LEWA" IN ENGLISH.
div.p: Mustapha Farha Kamel's new Buglish daily paper, which is to begin its existence shortly at Cairo, is from all accounts destined to be a very remarkable sample of Egyptian journalistio enterprise. The Egyptian "patriot" has engaged an Hibernian patriot to be the Editor-in-chief of his new Anglophobe organ, and the arrival of this Irish journalist is shortly expeoted. A special feature of the Pasha's English paper will be a series of articles by Little Englander Members of Parliament.

div.head: NIGHT OPERATIONS OF GARRISON.
div.p: Night operations will again be practised by the British garrison in Cai on the night of the 17th-18th inst. The garrison will be divided into two opposing forces, defence force, under command of Lieut.-Col. C. J. Markham, 1st King's Royal Rifle Corps, composed of a detachment of R.G.A. (with 4 mountain gans), a detachment of Roya! Engineers, and the 1st K.R.R. Corps, and an attacking force, ander Lieut. Col. J. H. Gideon, 1st Lancashire Fasi- liers.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passerger, mails, and general cargo.
The Mosa liner Se'i sailed from Liverpool on Wednesday, and is due here on or about the 26 h inst. with passengers,mails, and general cargo.
Hamburg & Anglo-American
NILE COMPANY.
River Transport of Goods between Alexandria and Caire. THREE SAILINGS A-WEEK. Agents at Alexandria ALEXANDRIA BONDED WAREHOUSE CO. LTD.

div.head:
THE SUEZ CANAL
TWO COMPETING ROUTES
div.p: It has been implied that a transit of 291 days between London and Hong Kong by the Canadian route would, if maintained, establish a permanent acceleration of seven days as compared with the transit via the Suez Canal. So far back as 1898 the scheduled transit for the English mail to Hong Kong from London, via Suez, was 18 days-one day less than the promised westerly transit-while delivery by the Suez route has in practice invariably been made in advance of schedule time. Moreover, while the present scheduled transit for the Suez route is 27 days, the actual carriage of the mail between London and Hong-Kong is made in less than 26 days-three to four days better, it is claimed, than the new "record" claimed for the Canadian route.

It will be remembered that the promoters of the Baghdad Railway have never ceased their efforts to interest French finance in that enterprise, and that financial influences in France have occasionally resisted the opposi tion made to the scheme on political grounds. These facts, the "Times" Paris correspondent says, give special interest to the attention attracted in financial circles in Paris by the discussion of the question by the Press of Calcutta and Bombay, which contends that the Baghdad Railway will never be a very brilliant affair from a business standpoint and can never seriously damage the Suez Canal.

div.head:
NILE TOURIST SEASON.
GERMAN FLAG ON THE NILE.
div.p: The German flag will not be flown instead of the Stars and Stripes by the steamers of the Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Company, but will be flown together with the British and American flags.

As a result of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company's fusion with the Hamburg-America Line, the former Company is building two new steamers, the Germania and the Nubia. There is no intention of build. ing two more vessels of a similar type for the season 1907-1908.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN COTTON IN SIND.
DISAPPOINTING RESULTS.
div.p: A Bombay Government resolution, reviewing the results of the cultivation of Egyptian cotton in Sind during 1905, remarks that they were not so promising as originally anticipated, owing partly to the unfavourable character of the season, but perhaps more largely to the very partial adoption only by the Sindhi zamindars of the Egyptian methods of cultivation, which are far more expensive and laborious than the indigenous methods to which they are accustomed. Owing to the pecaliar circumstances of the province it is feared that considerable time will elapse before the imperfect indigenous methods are supplanted by the Egyptian. Patience and persuasion are therefore commended to the authorities.

There was apparently some difficulty in disposing of last year's Indian "Egyptian" crop in India, only one firm purchasing it in any large quantity at fair prices; and these were lower than the prices obtained for the sample bales sent home by the authorities to Liverpool. The Government trust that, with the assurance obtained from Liverpool of the high quality of the cotton and the larger quantity to be grown this year, better prices will be secured and more bayers will come forward.

div.head: A SUDAN HERO.
div.p: Lieutenant-General Sir Archibald Hunter, Chief of the Western Command, India, who last week celebrated his fiftieth birthday, has rendered distinguished service to the army, notably in Egypt, where he spent thirteen years. He participated in five campaigns on the banks of the Nile, including the battles of Atbars and Khartoum. He secured the rank of Major-General at the age of forty, and in 1898 became a K.C.B. During the siege of Ladysmith he was second in command to Sir George White, and he distinguished himself during the sortie of Dec. 7, 1899. His decorations and other rewards during his service from 1885 to 1900 are four medals, a drzen clasps, a bronze star, the Medjidieh and Oamanieh Orders, the D.8.0., eleven mentions in despatches, four special promotions, and the thanks of Parlia ment. He carries two wounds-one severereceived on the Nile.

EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
RIDING BREECHES.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-free discussion.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST, LIMITED.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Dear Sir,- In your issue of the 27th August, you were good enough to publish my letter to you on the subject of the Egyptian Land and General Trust. In that letter I told the shareholders that there was no time to lose. I had not, however, an idea that I was cffering this caution with so much reason as now appears. By the time this reaches you any shareholders now in Egypt will be in possession of a notice dated London, 4th September, to the effect that a general meeting will be held here on the 14th idem. From the circumstances of the case this will probably resolve itself into another unimportant London gathering to deal with important issues. At this meeting we are to be told how "the Board are now dealing with offers which appear to be favourable for extendng the operations of the company"; of the arrangements under which "Mr. Mack is to take charge of the business of the company in Egypt," and presumably of the disappearance of Mr. Lonsdorfer from the list of directors. Many of us will, I am sure, be anxious to hear: (a) How money, is to be found tor extending operations? (b) What opportunities now exist comparable with those which have been the making of the "Estates," "Delta Lands," and others? (c) Why we are once more deprived of valuable local experience?
I am still, only more so,

div.head: ROYAL INNISKILLING FUSILIERS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE". Dear Sir,-In reply to the interesting letter of one of your correspondents in connection with the picture which appeared in "The Sphere" of June 16th last, of British soldiers surrounding the Sphinx, I beg to inform you that while it is true that this interesting picture was published in "The Sphere," our journal carefully guarded itself from the statement that the men actually on the Sphinx belonged to the Lancashire Fasiliers. We merely committed ourselves to the generalisation that British soldiers on reaching Egypt were naturally interested in the Sphinx, and that the Lancashires were specially so in view of their services in the campaign of 1801.

Not for worlds would one hurt the feelings of such a gallant regiment as the Royal Inniskilling Fasiliers, whose heroic deeds have found their most eloquent champion in Lord Macaulay, and whose services in Egypt in 1801 are also immortalised in their colours.- I am, dear Sir, Yours truly,
div.byline: THE EDITOR. "The Sphere" Great New St. Fetter Lane.

div.head: NILE FLOOD.
div.p: According to the "Sadan Time," the high Nile of this year has been unprecedented ia the modern history of the Sudan. Before Mabdism, however, higher Niles have been known. Sometimes, we are told, the waters of the Blue Nile threatened to overflow Khartoom, that the draining of rain water by natural methods was impracticable. An artificial stratagem had to be resorted to. All rain water was drained into a large "birka" near the river over a dyke by a steam lifting machine.

A native notable of experience informs us that a further rise of one metre over the present levels is necessary before the "bogr" lands can be naturally irrigated. He is confident of a farther heavy rainfall in this month which will result in the realization of this occurrence.

A heavy rainfall occurred on Monday, the 3d instant accompanied by a severe thunderstorm. The rain was typically tropical in its volume. The lightning and thunder continued far into the night, the storm subsiding early on Tuesday morning.

The rainfall amounted to 16 millimetres. On the 29th of August the Nile level at Rosaires was 19.20. A rise of one metre and ninety centimetres occurred on the 1st inst. when the level readings were 21.10. This sudden rise gives reason for anxiety and we understand that the Government is taking the necessary steps to protect Khartonm from its effect.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)
Pour quelques valeurs la baisse s'accentue, mais en général on est assez ferme. La National Bank perd 1/8 26 3/16, la
Cassa di Sconto 3/4 à 222 3/4, et la Delta Land
La Banque d'Orient recule ja qu'à 131, prix auquel elle est complétement délaissée.
Si le Trust se maintient relativement ferme
à 17/16, il n'en est pas de même de la Building
Lands qui est maintenant offerte à 5.
De 44 1/2 la part de fondateur Comptoir
tombe à 44.
En dépit de cette réaction, l'Union Foncière
se relève à 6 1/16 acheteurs.
Il y a eu quelques rares transactions sur les valears à l'ordre du jour: National Bank, Nangovich Hotels, Delta Land, eto.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: It is stated that Prince Omer Pasha Tous- Boun will very probably be appointed Guardian of the children of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, and that the Khedive and the Government have approved of the selection.

It is stated that the insurance money of the late Prince Mohamed Bay Ibrahim, which, it was asserted, really amounted to £1.000.000, WAR set aside by the deceased for the benefit of his male children.
It is stated that the Khedivah Mother has abandoned her intention of making the pilgrimage to Mecca this year.

Sir Brnest CAPPAl has taken delivery of a 45 horse power Mercedes antomobile with limousine saloon coschwork by Morel et Grammer. The interior of the vehicle is handsomely equipped, and contains various devices for the comfort of the passengers.
Mr. Chat way. the Administrator of the Alexandria Municipality, is at present in England. and was to have returned to Beypt on the 25th inst. We regret to learn, however, that be is suffering fr
Malta fever. H
attack of intermittent
racted the fever bere and has been unable to shake it off at home and is still very weak. It is doubtful therefore whether be will be able to return at the date of the expiry of his leave.
Mr. James Hewat, American Consular Agent at Alexandria, is due back from England by the 8.8. City of Oxford on Sunday next.
M. and Mme Elie M. Cattani are staying at the Hotel du Vieux Doelen, The Hague.
M. Adrian Girò is among the visitors at the Amstel Hotel, Amsterdam.
Mr. G. J. Hornblower, inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, has obtained leave of absence on private affairs for forty days.

Rear-Admiral William Carnegie Codrington Forsyth, whose death took place last week at Llanfoethen, North Wales, at the age of 57, was present at the bombardment of Alexandris, July, 1882, as lieutenant of the Invincible, and subsequently landed with a reconnoitring party daring the burning of the city. For this service he was promoted to commander, and received the Egyptian medal, with clasp, for Alexandria, and the Khedive's bronze star. His commission as captain bore date December 31. 1889, and that of rear-admiral, May 30, 1903. He retired from active service in the following year.

div.head:
PASSENGER LISTS.
ARRIVALS.
div.p: Le paquebot El Kabira de la Khedivial Mail arrivé le 11 septembre, avait à bord:- H.B. Major-General Ramzy et fils, H.E. Farid pacha, Hassan bey Saïd et sa femme, Aly bey Zatouh et sa femme, Mme Yando, M, Haptower, M. Moustapha Edhem, M. Hoarich Hanem, M. Alfred Rizzo, M. Antoine, M. Ekstein, M. Djemedjian, Salha Hanem, Mlle Marie, Mme Aziza Hanem, Hussein bey Wehly, M. et Mme Hassein Hasai, M. Maltas M. Rowsell, M. J. Rousso, M. Aninous, Dr. G. E. Post, Abdul Rahmen Eff., Mme E. Kevork, Mlle E. Mibati, Mme Golguez, M. B. Kinikli, M. A. Coumpas, M. E. Hatton, Fille Dimitriadis, M. Gasparian, M. et Mme le Comte Zizinia, Mme Pitobaxis, M. Apostolon, M. B. Maggiar, Mohamed Aly bey, M. Spiro Condoleon, Mme Josephine Moules, M. Joseph Salem, M. Gordon, M. Criston Goalmas, Mme Emmsnuel, M. et Mme Samarm, Mme Barbier et sa fille, 8.B. Edward Bey Elias, Mme et M. C. Pisodimos, M. Askar, Mme Askar et fils, M. C. Comanos, M. Anagnoston, Mme Umitrion et sa fille, Mme. Ida Falas, M. Zaldari, M. Aeitzas, M. Tuakara, M. Lytsioas, M. Veneris, M. Morpurgo, M. J. Capernavo, M. et Mme Ghedsfdjian, Mme Portucali bey et fille, M. et Mme Polizeni, M. D. Axelas Cavagnotti, ainsi que 157 passagers de 3me classe.
Per Moss 8.8. Tabor, arrived to day from Liverpool:-

Mr. H. C. Moss, Mr. J. B. Andrews, Mr. and Mrs. N. Khouri and 2 children, M. A. Baron, Mr. J. Milani, Mr. Max Vella, Mme Jalie Maller, Sisters della Croce, Charrach, Aubert, Mr. H. E. Clarke, Mr. A. C. Albani, Mr. H. Shirt, Mr. J. Enmans, Mr. J. Choworth, Sergt. J. H. Hendry, Mr. A. Marefield, Meears. Corregan, Mr. and Mrs. MacIntyre and 5 children, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gonsi and family, Mr. A. Bonici, and 22 deck passengers.
DEPARTURES.
Sont partis le 12 septembre 1906 par le paquebot Osmanieh de la Khedivial Mail Line
les passagers suivants:

Mr. and Mrs. Parkinson, M. Ahmed bey Bmin, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon, Mr. and Mrs. Reer, Mr. and Mrs. Spurgeon, Mme et Mile Gregoriadis, Tewfick bey. Tewfiok eff. Fahmy, MM. Bereketi, Constantin Frances00, Alberto Galboly, Guestarian, Hugo Tirminghans, Dr Drosso, Jean Mebaxopoulo, Mr. and Mrs. Williamson, A. N. Shoupis, Alex. Sednaoui, Aly R fast bey, Miss Young, Mme Georges Ralli, Costi Cezzika, Anastassion et sa sœur, Jean Delenda, Walker, Jean Chelmis G. Svorono, Negib bey, Hassan eftendi Hilmi, Zakaria, Badek, Miss Bemker, Miss Rees maid, Mrs. Williamson maid, Mme Esther Hayat, M. Cherido, Poriasi, Tonniolo, Hilmi effend, Mohamed Chafik, Bonne Mme Ralli, Miss Zoarofski, Mile Zakos et 80 de 8me classe.

div.head:
EGYPT AND PAN-ISLAMISM.
"EGYPT FOR THE EGYPTIANS."
div.p: (Suite et Fin)

On nous & accusés de recevoir notre mot d'ordre de Constantinople, parce que nous avons soutena la caure de ls Turquie dans l'affaire de Tabah. Mais je voudrais bien savoir si les célèbres adversaires du régime tare actuel, Ahmed Rizs bey, Ismail Kamal bey et Khalil Khaled effendi, sont des agents de Yildiz pour avoir Fontenn publiquement la Turquie dans cette affaire! Et par qui les écrivains anglais qui ont adopté notre manière de voir ont-ils été inspirés ?

Etions-nous au service des Boers et des Japonais pour avoir sympathisé avec eux et admiré leur étonnant courage et leur admirable patriotisme 1 Abrait-il été vraiment patriotique de notre part de soutenir l'Angleterre contre la Turquie ? Y a-t-il un seal Français qui admettrait que ses compatriotes soient avec l'Allemagne contre la Russie si une latte s'en- gsgesit entre ces deux pays?

Et si nous avons pris parti pour la France dans le conflit de Fachoda, pourquoi s'étonner de nous voir avec la Turquie dans la question de Tabah? Nous avons acutenu la cause tarque parce que nous vous jugé que le droit était de son côté. Et puis il aurait fallu nous prendre pour des naïfs et des ignorants pour nous faire croire que la politique anglaise, qui nous a ravi le Soudan et les ports de la mer Rouge, défendait les droits de l'Egypte à Tabah!

Dire que nous voulons voir les Tarca maitres de l'Egypte est ane absurdité. Ce que nous voulons, c'est voir la question d'Egypte posée définitivement devant l'Europe. Toutes les paissances ont des intérêts considérables en Egypte. Son sort ne peut donc dépendre de nous seals, et après l'évacuation de notre territoire par les troupes anglaises, la question n'aura qu'une seule solution: le rétablissement des droits conférés à l'Egypte par le traité de Londres de 1840 et par les firmans impériaux, en dotant le pays d'ane Constitution libérale.

Depuis l'accord abglo-français, quelques journalistes français ont ora de lear devoir de mener en Egypte une campagne favorable l'occupation anglaise. D'autres, voulant sans doute servir leurs propres intérêts, ont accentué la note et ont osé nier l'existence d'une patrie égyptienne. Cette attitude ne nous a ni étonnés ni désolés, ayant déjà vu des hommes politiques, occupant de hautes situations, faire de même. Plus nous avançons, plus nous comptons sur nos propres forces.

Mais les attaques de cs journalistes ont fait le plus grand mal à la France parmi la classe éclairée ainsi que parmi le peuple. S'ils voulaient réellement servir leur pays, ces journalistes auraient dû comprendre que l'élite de la nation égyptienne a été instruite en France ou par des Français, qu'elle forme le premier factear da progrès et le seal intermé- diaire possible entre les Européens et le people égyptien et que la France a le droit d'être fière d'avoir ainsi contribué à réveiller l'Egypte et à lui donner une conscience nationale.

Tout homme impartial reconnalt que ce n'est pas nous qui avons changé de politique, mais bien ceux qui d'adversaires implacables de la diplomatie anglaise sont devenus ses meilleurs amis et auxiliaires. Ce n'est pas nous qui avons sacrifié notre amitié envers la France pour chercher d'autres amis. C'est la France qui nous a abandonnés.

Il est donc bien compréhensible que nous nous sentions lésés par une politique qui nous a fait tant de mal. Mais c'est une erreur de croire que nous avons oublié le passé, l'histoire et tout ce que la France a fait en Egypte. Nous savons distinguer entre la France poli tique et la France scientifique et littéraire.

On nous dit que nous attaquons la France dans nos écrits. Or, il faut nous lire pour nous comprendre. Nous critiquons tout ce qui nous paralt critiquable. Entre la critique et l'attaque il y a une bien grande différence. Nous essayors d'éclairer les puissances européennes sur les vraies souffrances de leurs sujets, et nous sommes convaincus de faire une ceuvre atile et humanitaire.
Voulant attirer l'attention de la France sur leur état, des Tunisiens et des Algériens adressent parfois des lettres aux journaux masulmans d'Egypte. Est-ce un crime?

Je ne crois pas qu'il y ait en France an seul homme d'Etat qui soit partisan de la politique d'étouffement et d'arbitraire. Que la France écoute ses sujets musulmans, qu'elle fasse ce qu'elle peut pour lear relèvement-at elle peat tont-et tous les musulmans da globe lui seront reconnaissants! Il est, en somme, humain de demander, d'exiger même qu'ayant aboli l'esclavage des hommes, l'Europe, et la France avant tout autre pays, travaillent à abolir l'esclavage des nations.

Cenx qui nous reprochent de critiquer qualquefois la politique française oublient tout le bien que nous avons dit, à maintes reprises, des hommes et des wavres qui honorent la France. M. Jonnart, le gouverneur de l'Algérie, n'a-t-il pas été loué par la presse musulmane d'Egypte, et par le Lewa le premier, quand on nous asssuré qu'il était juste et bien intentionné envers les musulmans Et puis peut-on sérieasement nous reprocher d'aser de notre droit de critique et peat on considérer comme un péché notre désir de voir les musulmans et tous ceux qui souffrent plus beareax ou moins malheureux ?
an
L'aatear de l'article sur le "panislamisme" a affirmé que je suis devenu un and ami de l'Allemagne, que je reç is même des articles des diplomates allemands et que M. Max
